utterances: You don't have Nixon to kick around anymore.

BUSH: But I'm the decider.
Byaah.
Every Wednesday, NPR's political editor and our Political Junkie, Ken Rudin, joins us.
This week, what do the words impeachment, beautification and Watergate have in common?
The politicians and political figures who died in 2007.
We'll check in with an up and coming political reporter in Iowa.
And we want to hear from those of you who've spent your own money and time to campaign in the snows of Iowa and New Hampshire.
Whether you went Clean for Gene or rode to the sound of the guns with Pat Buchanan, or if you're out there this year: 800-989-8255.
E-mail us: talk@npr.org.
You can also tell us your story about why you decided to volunteer for a campaign in Iowa or New Hampshire on our blog.
That's at npr.org/blogofthenation.
Later on in the program, well, we have an e-mail challenge for you.
What's the strangest, most unwieldy, hardest-to-explain item you've ever tried to get aboard a commercial airliner?
Again, the e-mail address is talk@npr.org.
First, though, the Political Junkie, Ken Rudin, joins us from his home just outside of Washington D.C.
Hey, Ken.
Hi, Neal.
And I want to ask you, first of all, about the campaign at this point.
A lot of the candidates left Iowa for the holidays, I guess, except for Chris Dodd.
Well, Chris Dodd moved his wife and his two young children into Iowa several months ago because, basically, his whole campaign has been Iowa, as has many candidates.
But the Christmas holidays, or at least, Christmas Day is over, and that means most candidates are back in Iowa, but not all of them.
And not an extraordinary amount of political news this week -some fresh polls, but they just seem to show what every other polls seem to show.
Well, they do.
But again, eight days is still - eight days before Iowa - 2004, I was still saying Howard Dean was going to win and he finished third.
And I guess, you know, it doesn't matter what Ken Rudin has to say.
But I think a lot of things can change in the last couple of days.
And it looks like that large Mike Huckabee lead on the Republican side over Mitt Romney may be narrowing somewhat.
Huckabee still seems to have a lead, but there are some indications that Romney's negative campaign against Huckabee is bearing some fruits.
So, again, plenty of time to go.
And a lot of focus also on the state of New Hampshire, which comes up just five days after Iowa.
Right.
And that's John McCain's bid to become the 2008 comeback kid.
He is doing really well in New Hampshire.
He is narrowing the gap between himself and the frontrunner Mitt Romney.
And if McCain, who is campaigning in Iowa today - if he does some kind of a decent showing in the Hawkeye State on January 3rd, that could really benefit him five days later when New Hampshire votes.
All right.
Later in the program, we're going to be talking with callers and e-mailers about why they went to volunteer in the snows of New Hampshire or Iowa, for what candidate, at what time: 800-989-9255.
E-mail us: talk@npr.org.
But first, we're going to be talking also about some of the politicians and political figures who left the scene this past year.
And Ken, I guess, we'll begin with your trivia question.
Well, I'm glad to talk - there are so many influential people who left the scene in 2007.
One of them, of course, is Norman Mailer.
You don't think of him as being a political person, although, of course, he's a great, you know, writer and everything.
But he did won for mayor of New York City in 1969.
So the trivia question - this may not be the toughest trivia question - but, who is his running mate for city council president that year and what was their slogan?
What were they pledging to do in that campaign?
Norman Mailer's running mate and also the slogan as they ran for mayor back in 1969 in New York City.
But let's talk about some of the people who did past away earlier this year.
And we have to begin with the man who is - well, he will be best remembered for an impeachment, and that's the clip of tape we're going to play.
But Henry Hyde did a lot of things - but among them was to bring charges against the president of the United States, William Jefferson Clinton.
(Soundbite of William Jefferson Clinton's impeachment trial)

So what if the president has undermined the integrity of his office, has brought disrepute on the presidency, has betrayed his trust as president and has acted in a manner subversive of the rule of law and justice, to the manifest injury of the people of the United States?
That's an awful lot to dismiss with a brush-off, to ignore with a mere so-what
Henry Hyde, then the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, appealing to the United States Senate.
It didn't make it through, but appealing to the United States Senate to uphold impeachment charges against President Clinton.
Right.
And, of course, an interesting Henry Hyde was first elected at the Congress in 1974 during the Nixon impeachment year.

But Henry Hyde, for all the, you know, the things that liberal - the problems that liberals had with him - certainly on abortion, he was not so much the author - I learned that only recently - that he did not write the Hyde amendment.
And what was that like?
We're broadcasting today with a live audience in NPR's Studio 4A and also with us are New Orleans musicians David Mooney and Derek Douget.
We'll be joined later in the program by longtime New Orleans R&B artist and Rock and Roll Hall of Famer Allan Toussaint.
But first, Derek Douget and David Mooney, let me begin you guys with a question I guess everybody asks anybody from New Orleans these days.
How'd you get out?
I left before.
I left a day before and evacuated to Gonzales, which is about 60 miles west-northwest of New Orleans.
Any doubts in your mind about staying, Derek?
No.
No?
No.
David, what about you?
Well, we left before as well, my wife and I.
And we went up to Mississippi to stay with some friends and watched it on the TV, like everybody else, when things got really bad; hardly brought anything with us.
And from there, we made our way here.
Well, we're glad that both of you got out and I hope everybody...
Thank you.
...in both your families is OK.
Thanks.
How about a tune?
Sure.
Sure.
Sure.
